awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:   SusChEM:  Mechanistic origins of synergetic effects in plasma catalysis
awd_abstract_narration:
1703211 / 1703439
PI: Oehrlein, Gottlieb S.   /  Bruggeman, Peter J.   
Institution: University of Maryland College Park / University of Minnesota-Twin Cities

The proposed collaborative research project aims at using a well-characterized atmospheric-pressure plasma source to enable well-controlled interactions of the plasma with earth-abundant catalysts. The activations of catalysts using plasmas holds great promise for increasing the efficiency of catalytic systems with potential applications in a broad spectrum industries, including chemical and materials synthesis, environmental remediation, and energy generation. The overriding goal of the proposed project is to investigate the underlying mechanisms that are responsible for the synergistic effects of plasma with catalysts. The plan is to correlate the magnitude of the plasma catalytic synergistic effect(s) with incident reactive species fluxes, along with changes in catalyst surface properties, and surface electronic structure. A careful systematic comparison of the different catalysts may elucidate the microscopic origins of the synergistic effect and explore potential plasma activation of thermally inactive catalysts. The project may lead to better understanding of the requirements for plasma conditions and catalysts to fully exploit the synergistic potential of plasma-catalyst systems.

A mechanistic study is proposed that is aimed at providing atomistic insights to unravel the key mechanisms responsible for the synergistic effect(s) during plasma-catalyst interactions. Iron, nickel, cobalt, and copper supported catalysts (on alumina and silica supports) will be employed in this study. These catalysts vary strongly in thermal catalytic activities due to different electronic structure and surface-catalytic mechanisms. The investigation will be focused on studying atomistic surface modifications of the catalysts for the oxygen/methane model system as the plasma-surface interaction conditions are changed. This will include the impact of these surface changes on the products formed and their formation rates. Gas phase characterization will be achieved by molecular beam mass spectrometry and two-photon laser induced fluorescence. Surface characterization will include ellipsometry, ultra-violet and x-ray induced photoemission spectroscopy coupled with thermal desorption, and Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy.  The proposed approach has the potential to make transformative changes to the current state-of-the-art by enabling a mechanistically informed design of catalysts ideally suited for plasma-catalyst synergies. In addition to training graduate and undergraduate students, the investigators plan to develop course material on plasma-catalysis and an interactive lecture for middle school students.

por.por_cntn:
The activation of catalysts using low temperature plasmas holds great promise for increasing the efficiency of thermally driven catalytic systems which are heavily used for chemical conversions in industry. The lack of understanding of the fundamental mechanisms underpinning plasma-catalyst interactions currently impedes the development and implementation of large scale plasma-catalysis enabled technologies. In the framework of this project, we have investigated the underlying mechanisms that are responsible for the synergistic effects of plasma with catalysts in the context of partial oxidation of methane (conversion of methane and oxygen to methanol).

We have implemented and extended the capabilities of molecular beam mass spectrometry to measure plasma-produced species fluxes to catalytic substrates at atmospheric pressure. In addition, we developed plasma control strategies that allow to vary densities and fluxes of targeted plasma-produced reactive species. Our collaborator at the University of Maryland complemented this work with surface characterization of plasma-exposed catalysts under the same plasma conditions allowing to correlate the obtained species flux variations with changes in surface coverages and chemical conversion. Key outcomes of these collaborative studies include the important role of O radicals in plasma catalysis for methane-oxygen mixtures as show by strong correlations of O fluxes with changes in surface coverages and conversion.

We have also identified important synergetic effects in plasma catalysis on an earth-abundent iron catalyst without external heating. In this case, we showed the important role of secondary, long-lived radicals such as the methyl peroxide radical to play a dominant role in the synergy. This outcome experimentally showed the important transport limitations in plasma-catalysis and the need for new reactor concepts to overcome such limitations and enhance chemical conversion efficiencies.

The above described research results have provided insights that have the potential to contribute to a more mechanistically informed design of plasma-catalyst reactors. The activation of catalysts using plasmas holds great promise for increasing the efficiency of catalytic systems with potential applications in a broad spectrum of industries, including chemical and materials synthesis, environmental remediation, and energy generation. In addition, the project enabled the training of graduate students, the development of an interactive lecture on plasmas for middle school students, which was part of the Eureka summer program at the University of Minnesota and the editing of the 2022 Plasma Roadmap.
